continentalDishes.name: Jollof Rice with Grilled Chicken and Plantain Puree
continentalDishes.description: A Nigerian staple elevated with continental plating techniques. Saffron-infused jollof rice served with succulent grilled chicken and a smooth plantain puree.

platingTechniques.name: Stacked Jollof with Swirled Puree
platingTechniques.description: A modern presentation featuring a timbale of jollof rice and an artistic swirl of plantain puree.
steps: Use a ring mold to create a neat stack of jollof rice in the center of the plate.
Pipe a smooth plantain puree around the base of the rice stack in a circular or abstract swirl.
Slice grilled chicken and arrange it leaning against the rice stack.
Garnish with fresh herbs like parsley or basil and a sprinkle of paprika.
Optional: Add a small drizzle of chili oil for color and flavor.
tips: Ensure the jollof rice is firm enough to hold its shape in the mold.
The plantain puree should be smooth and easily pipeable.
Consider the color contrast between the red rice and yellow puree.

platingTechniques.name: Deconstructed Jollof Platter
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the individual components of jollof in an artistic and approachable manner.
steps: Arrange a bed of fluffy saffron rice on one side of a rectangular plate.
Place a small portion of the stewed tomato and pepper base in a separate small bowl or ramekin.
Display grilled chicken skewers or pieces alongside the rice.
Create small quenelles of plantain puree and place them strategically on the plate.
Garnish with fresh herbs, microgreens, and edible flowers for visual appeal.
tips: Highlight the vibrant colors of each component.
Use different textures to create interest.
Ensure each element is seasoned well individually.

continentalDishes.name: Peppered Snails with Garlic Butter and Herb Crostini
continentalDishes.description: Succulent peppered snails pan-seared in garlic butter, served with crispy herb-infused crostini.

platingTechniques.name: Radial Snail Arrangement
platingTechniques.description: Arranging the peppered snails in a circular pattern around a central element.
steps: Place a small mound of herb crostini in the center of the plate.
Arrange the peppered snails radially around the crostini, with the open ends facing outwards.
Drizzle the garlic butter sauce over the snails and crostini.
Garnish with fresh herbs and a sprinkle of red pepper flakes for color.
tips: Ensure the snails are cooked and tender.
The garlic butter sauce should be flavorful and not too greasy.
The crostini should be crispy and provide a textural contrast.

platingTechniques.name: Peppered Snail Skewers with Dipping Sauce
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the snails on skewers for an elegant and easy-to-eat appetizer.
steps: Thread the cooked peppered snails onto small skewers.
Arrange the skewers on a platter or plate.
Serve with a small bowl of the garlic butter sauce for dipping.
Garnish with fresh herbs and lemon wedges.
tips: Use appropriately sized skewers to prevent overcrowding.
Ensure the snails are securely threaded.
The dipping sauce should be served warm.

continentalDishes.name: Yam Pottage with Smoked Fish Velouté and Crispy Onions
continentalDishes.description: A creamy and flavorful yam pottage elevated with a smooth smoked fish velouté and crispy fried onions.

platingTechniques.name: Layered Pottage Bowl
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the yam pottage and smoked fish velouté in distinct layers within a bowl.
steps: Spoon a layer of the creamy yam pottage into the bottom of a bowl.
Gently pour a layer of the smoked fish velouté over the pottage.
Top with crispy fried onions for texture and visual appeal.
Garnish with fresh herbs like chopped parsley or chives.
tips: Ensure both the pottage and velouté have a smooth and consistent texture.
The layers should be distinct but complementary in flavor.
The crispy onions should be golden brown and not greasy.

platingTechniques.name: Yam Pottage Quenelle with Smoked Fish Drizzle
platingTechniques.description: A more refined presentation featuring a quenelle of yam pottage and an artistic drizzle of smoked fish velouté.
steps: Use two spoons to create a smooth quenelle of yam pottage on a plate.
Drizzle the smoked fish velouté around the quenelle in an abstract pattern.
Scatter crispy fried onions around the plate.
Garnish with microgreens or edible flowers for a touch of elegance.
tips: Practice the quenelle technique for a smooth and uniform shape.
The velouté should be thin enough to drizzle easily.
Consider the color contrast between the pottage and the velouté.

continentalDishes.name: Grilled Catfish with Sauce Vierge and Roasted Root Vegetables
continentalDishes.description: Flaky grilled catfish served with a vibrant and fresh sauce vierge and accompanied by roasted seasonal root vegetables.

platingTechniques.name: Centerpiece Fish with Vegetable Scatter
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the grilled catfish as the main focus with the roasted vegetables artfully scattered around.
steps: Place the grilled catfish fillet in the center of the plate.
Spoon the sauce vierge generously over the fish.
Arrange the roasted root vegetables around the fish in a visually appealing manner.
Garnish with fresh herbs and a lemon wedge.
tips: Ensure the catfish is cooked through but still moist.
The sauce vierge should be fresh and vibrant.
The roasted vegetables should be tender and slightly caramelized.

platingTechniques.name: Layered Vegetables with Fish on Top
platingTechniques.description: Creating a bed of roasted vegetables and placing the grilled catfish on top, drizzled with sauce vierge.
steps: Arrange the roasted root vegetables in an even layer on the plate.
Place the grilled catfish fillet on top of the vegetables.
Spoon the sauce vierge over the fish, allowing some to drizzle down the sides.
Garnish with fresh herbs and a sprinkle of sea salt.
tips: The vegetable layer should be neat and visually appealing.
The fish should be positioned attractively on top.
Ensure the sauce vierge complements the flavors of the fish and vegetables.

continentalDishes.name: Plantain Fritters with Spicy Tomato and Basil Dip
continentalDishes.description: Sweet and savory plantain fritters served with a tangy and spicy tomato and basil dipping sauce.

platingTechniques.name: Artfully Scattered Fritters
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the plantain fritters in a seemingly random but visually appealing arrangement.
steps: Arrange the fried plantain fritters on a platter or plate, allowing some to overlap slightly.
Place a small bowl of the spicy tomato and basil dip in the center or on the side.
Garnish with fresh basil leaves and a sprinkle of powdered sugar for contrast.
tips: Ensure the fritters are golden brown and crispy.
The dipping sauce should be flavorful and have a good consistency.
Consider the color contrast between the golden fritters and the red sauce.

platingTechniques.name: Stacked Fritter Tower with Dip Drizzle
platingTechniques.description: Creating a small tower of plantain fritters with the dipping sauce drizzled over.
steps: Stack the plantain fritters to form a small tower.
Drizzle the spicy tomato and basil dip over the tower, allowing it to cascade down the sides.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh basil on top.
tips: Ensure the fritters are stable enough to form a tower.
The dipping sauce should be thick enough to cling to the fritters.
Consider the height and visual impact of the tower.

continentalDishes.name: Ofada Rice with Ayamase and Smoked Fish Garnish
continentalDishes.description: Unpolished Ofada rice served with the intensely flavored Ayamase sauce and garnished with flaked smoked fish.

platingTechniques.name: Molded Ofada Rice with Ayamase Pool
platingTechniques.description: Using a mold to shape the Ofada rice and creating a pool of Ayamase sauce around it.
steps: Use a ring mold or a small bowl to shape the cooked Ofada rice in the center of the plate.
Spoon the Ayamase sauce around the molded rice, creating a vibrant green pool.
Arrange pieces of cooked meat or smoked fish on top of the rice.
Garnish with thinly sliced red onions and fresh herbs.
tips: Ensure the Ofada rice is slightly sticky to hold its shape.
The Ayamase sauce should be thick enough to form a pool without spreading too much.
Consider the color contrast between the brown rice and green sauce.

platingTechniques.name: Ofada Rice and Ayamase Stripes
platingTechniques.description: Creating alternating stripes of Ofada rice and Ayamase sauce for a visually striking presentation.
steps: On a rectangular plate, create parallel stripes of cooked Ofada rice and Ayamase sauce.
Place pieces of cooked meat or smoked fish along the stripes.
Garnish with a sprinkle of chopped bell peppers and fresh herbs.
tips: Use piping bags or spoons to create neat and even stripes.
Ensure the stripes have good color contrast.
Consider the balance of rice and sauce in each bite.

continentalDishes.name: Moi Moi with Grilled Prawns and Parsley Oil Drizzle
continentalDishes.description: Steamed bean pudding (Moi Moi) served with succulent grilled prawns and a vibrant parsley-infused oil.

platingTechniques.name: Deconstructed Moi Moi with Prawn Skewers
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the individual components of Moi Moi in an artistic and modern way.
steps: Create small quenelles or mounds of the Moi Moi mixture and gently pan-fry or bake them.
Grill the prawns on skewers until pink and cooked through.
Arrange the Moi Moi quenelles and prawn skewers on a plate.
Drizzle parsley oil over the Moi Moi and prawns.
Garnish with fresh herbs and edible flowers.
tips: The Moi Moi should be cooked but still moist.
The prawns should be grilled to perfection.
The parsley oil should be vibrant green and flavorful.

platingTechniques.name: Molded Moi Moi with Grilled Prawn Topping
platingTechniques.description: Using a mold to create elegant shapes of Moi Moi topped with grilled prawns.
steps: Steam the Moi Moi mixture in individual molds (e.g., ramekins or small cups).
Once cooked, gently unmold the Moi Moi onto a plate.
Top each molded Moi Moi with one or two grilled prawns.
Drizzle parsley oil around the base of the Moi Moi.
Garnish with a sprig of fresh parsley.
tips: Ensure the molds are lightly oiled for easy release.
The prawns should be attractively placed on top.
The parsley oil adds a touch of color and flavor.

continentalDishes.name: Suya Spiced Grilled Chicken with Herbed Couscous
continentalDishes.description: Tender grilled chicken marinated in traditional Nigerian Suya spices, served with fluffy herbed couscous.

platingTechniques.name: Couscous Bed with Suya Chicken
platingTechniques.description: Creating a bed of herbed couscous and placing the Suya spiced grilled chicken on top.
steps: Spoon the herbed couscous onto the plate, creating a soft bed.
Place the grilled Suya spiced chicken on top of the couscous.
Arrange grilled onions and bell peppers alongside the chicken.
Drizzle with a little olive oil and garnish with fresh herbs.
tips: The couscous should be light and fluffy.
The chicken should be cooked through and have a nice char from the Suya spices.
The grilled vegetables add color and flavor.

platingTechniques.name: Suya Chicken Skewers with Molded Couscous
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the Suya chicken on skewers with a neatly molded portion of herbed couscous.
steps: Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto skewers and grill until cooked.
Use a ring mold or small bowl to shape the herbed couscous on the plate.
Place the grilled chicken skewers alongside the molded couscous.
Garnish with a sprinkle of Suya spice and fresh herbs.
tips: Ensure the chicken pieces are evenly sized for uniform cooking.
The couscous mold should be neat and hold its shape.
The Suya spice garnish enhances the visual appeal and flavor.

continentalDishes.name: Kunun Zaki Panna Cotta with Fruit Compote
continentalDishes.description: A creamy Italian dessert infused with the flavors of the popular Nigerian drink, Kunun Zaki, served with a fresh fruit compote.

platingTechniques.name: Panna Cotta in Glass with Fruit Topping
platingTechniques.description: Serving the Kunun Zaki panna cotta in elegant glasses topped with the fruit compote.
steps: Pour the set Kunun Zaki panna cotta into individual serving glasses.
Spoon the fresh fruit compote over the top of the panna cotta.
Garnish with a sprig of mint or a small edible flower.
tips: Ensure the panna cotta has a smooth and creamy texture.
The fruit compote should be fresh and flavorful.
Use clear glasses to showcase the layers.

platingTechniques.name: Unmolded Panna Cotta with Fruit Coulis
platingTechniques.description: Gently unmolding the panna cotta onto a plate and serving it with a fruit coulis.
steps: Lightly oil ramekins or molds before pouring in the panna cotta mixture.
Once set, gently unmold the panna cotta onto a chilled plate.
Blend some of the fruit compote to create a smooth coulis and drizzle it around the panna cotta.
Garnish with fresh fruit slices and a sprinkle of chopped nuts.
tips: Dip the bottom of the ramekin in warm water for easy unmolding.
The fruit coulis should have a smooth and pourable consistency.
Consider the color contrast between the panna cotta and the fruit coulis.

continentalDishes.name: Zobo Infused Sorbet with Hibiscus Syrup
continentalDishes.description: A refreshing sorbet infused with the tangy and floral flavors of the Nigerian Zobo drink, served with a homemade hibiscus syrup.

platingTechniques.name: Sorbet Scoops in Elegant Glassware
platingTechniques.description: Presenting scoops of the vibrant Zobo sorbet in stylish glasses.
steps: Scoop the Zobo sorbet into chilled glasses (e.g., martini glasses or coupe glasses).
Drizzle the hibiscus syrup over the sorbet.
Garnish with fresh berries or a slice of lime.
tips: Chill the glasses beforehand to keep the sorbet cold.
The hibiscus syrup should have a good consistency and flavor.
Consider the color contrast between the dark red sorbet and the garnishes.

platingTechniques.name: Sorbet Quenelles with Syrup Swirl
platingTechniques.description: Creating elegant quenelles of the Zobo sorbet and serving them with an artistic swirl of hibiscus syrup.
steps: Use two spoons to create smooth quenelles of the Zobo sorbet on a chilled plate.
Drizzle the hibiscus syrup around the sorbet quenelles in a decorative swirl.
Garnish with fresh mint leaves or edible flowers.
tips: Ensure the sorbet is firm enough to hold its shape as quenelles.
The hibiscus syrup should be thick enough to create a defined swirl.
Consider the negative space on the plate to highlight the sorbet.

continentalDishes.name: Puff Puff with Chocolate Ganache and Salted Caramel Drizzle
continentalDishes.description: The popular Nigerian fried dough (Puff Puff) elevated with a rich chocolate ganache and a sweet and salty caramel drizzle.

platingTechniques.name: Stacked Puff Puff with Ganache Cascade
platingTechniques.description: Arranging the Puff Puff in a tower with the chocolate ganache cascading down.
steps: Arrange the fried Puff Puff in a neat stack on a plate.
Pour the warm chocolate ganache over the top of the stack, allowing it to drip down the sides.
Drizzle salted caramel sauce over the ganache.
Garnish with a sprinkle of flaky sea salt.
tips: Ensure the Puff Puff are golden brown and not too oily.
The chocolate ganache should be smooth and glossy.
The salted caramel drizzle adds a contrasting flavor and visual appeal.

platingTechniques.name: Puff Puff Skewers with Chocolate and Caramel Dips
platingTechniques.description: Presenting the Puff Puff on skewers with separate bowls of chocolate ganache and salted caramel for dipping.
steps: Thread the fried Puff Puff onto small skewers.
Arrange the skewers on a platter.
Serve with small bowls of warm chocolate ganache and salted caramel sauce for dipping.
Garnish with a sprinkle of cocoa powder or chopped nuts.
tips: Use appropriately sized skewers.
Ensure the dipping sauces are served warm.
Provide napkins as this can be a messy but delicious treat.
